N. A licensee seeking renewal shall complete a Board-approved course of 2 hours in abuse and neglect.

O. The 2-hour, Board-approved course in abuse and neglect required by §N of this regulation shall:

(1) Be completed by each licensee every other renewal cycle;

(2) Relate to Maryland law on the subject of abuse and neglect; and

(3) Count toward the 30 full hours of required continuing education.

P. A dentist seeking renewal shall complete a 2-hour Board- approved course on proper prescribing and disposal of prescription drugs, which shall count toward the 30 full hours of required continuing education.

Q. A dentist seeking renewal shall complete a 2-hour Board- approved course on proper prescribing and disposal of prescription drugs, which shall count toward the 30 full hours of required continuing education.

R. Optional Pro Bono Program. A licensee seeking renewal may receive up to 8 continuing education hours for providing volunteer pro bono dental or dental hygiene services in accordance with Regulation .07 of this chapter.

S. Cultural Competency, Military Culture, and Implicit Bias Training. A licensee may receive up to a combined total of 4 continuing education hours for Board-approved courses on:

(1) Cultural competency;

(2) Military culture; or

(3) Implicit bias training.

T. A licensee may receive up to 2 continuing education hours for Board-approved courses on abuse and neglect.

U. A study club course shall first receive Board approval before attendees may receive continuing education credit for attendance at the study club meeting.

V. Dentists and dental hygienists may receive one continuing education credit for attending a regularly scheduled open session Board meeting in its entirety.

W. The Board shall issue a certificate of completion to dentists and dental hygienists who attend a regularly scheduled open session Board meeting in its entirety.

X. A dentist or a dental hygienist may earn up to two continuing education credits per renewal period for attendance at regularly scheduled open session Board meetings.

Y. A licensee who has received a license within 6 months of graduation from an approved dental or dental hygiene school is not required to fulfill the continuing education requirements of the Board for the first renewal following initial licensure.

Z. A licensee who is on inactive status shall provide evidence of compliance with the continuing education requirements of the Board for the 2-year period preceding application for reactivation of the licensee's license.

AA. A licensee who fails to obtain the required continuing education due to disability or retirement shall comply with this regulation within 6 months of the licensee's return to practice.

BB. The infection control course identified in §M of this regulation shall be a single 3-hour course which teaches the practices contained in the document Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Summary of Infection Prevention Practices in Dental Settings: Basic Expectations for Safe Care, Atlanta, GA: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, US Dept. of Health and Human Services; October 2016, or its successor document.

.05 Time Frame for Completing Continuing Education.

A. A. The period for completing continuing education requirements extends for a 2-year period from July 1 through June 30 of the second year following the effective date of the license.

B. The 2-year period in which the continuing education shall be completed ends on June 30 of the year in which the license is due for renewal.

C. For the renewal period beginning on June 1, 2025, only, the period for completing continuing education requirements extends for the period January 1, 2023, through June 30, 2025.

.06 Course and Program Eligibility.

A. Eligibility Guidelines.

(1) General. With the exceptions listed in §A(2) of this regulation, only those courses or programs that satisfy the following eligibility guidelines qualify for continuing education credit for license renewal:

(a) The course or program is designed to enhance the licensee's clinical knowledge and ability to treat dental patients; and

(b) The course or program is offered by a Board-approved sponsor.

(2) Abuse and Neglect Courses, Cultural Competency Courses, Military Culture Courses, Implicit Bias Training Courses, and Pro Bono Programs. To qualify for continuing education credit for license renewal:

(a) The mandatory course in abuse and neglect identified in Regulation .04N and O of this chapter:

(i) Does not need to be designed to enhance the licensee’s clinical knowledge and ability to treat dental patients; and

(ii) Shall be offered by a Board-approved sponsor;

(b) Cultural competency courses:

(i) Do not need to enhance the licensee’s clinical knowledge; and

(ii) Shall be offered by a Board-approved sponsor;

(c) Military culture courses:

(i) Do not need to enhance the licensee’s clinical knowledge; and

(ii) Shall be offered by a Board-approved sponsor;

(d) Implicit bias training courses:

(i) Do not need to be designed to enhance the licensee’s clinical knowledge and ability to treat dental patients; and

(ii) Shall be approved by the Maryland Office of Minority Health and Health Disparities.

(e) Pro bono programs:

(i) Do not need to enhance the licensee’s clinical knowledge and ability to treat dental patients; and

(ii) Shall be offered by a Board-approved sponsor.

B. Excluded Courses and Programs. Courses and programs that are not approved for continuing education credit for license renewal include, but are not limited to, the subjects of:

(1) Money management;

(2) Personal finance;

(3) Personal business matters;

(4) With the exception of those courses or programs on cultural competency, military culture, and implicit bias training courses, cultural subjects;

(5) Personal health and recreation;

(6) Politics;

(7) Memory training; and

(8) Speed reading.

.07 Pro Bono Dental and Dental Hygiene Services.

A. Beginning on the effective date of this regulation dentists or dental hygienists may receive continuing education credit for providing volunteer pro bono dental and dental hygiene services within the State as provided in this regulation.

B. A dentist or dental hygienist may provide volunteer pro bono care at a Board-approved program that:

(1) Is a non-profit entity or event; and

(2) Provides substantial pro bono dental services to the indigent or dentally underserved populations.

C. With the exception of food, lodging, and parking fees, a dentist or dental hygienist may not receive direct or indirect remuneration of any kind, including but not limited to remuneration for materials purchased or used.

D. With the exception of those pro bono services provided at a dentist’s or dental hygienist’s office as outlined in §E of this regulation, the program shall require a dentist or dental hygienist to sign in and sign out daily upon commencement and termination of the provision of services.

E. A dentist or dental hygienist may provide pro bono services for continuing education credit at the dentist’s or dental hygienist’s office:

(1) If the patient is referred to the dentist or dental hygienist by a Board-approved nonprofit entity that provides substantial pro bono dental services to the indigent or dentally underserved populations; and

(2) If the Board provides prior approval of the provision of the dental or dental hygiene services.

F. Continuing education credit shall be calculated based on the time a dentist or dental hygienist has actually dedicated to the performance of dental or dental hygiene services.

G. Continuing education credit shall be calculated at the ratio of 1 continuing education credit for each 60 minutes of patient services.

H. Credit may not be provided for missed appointments.

I. Board-approved nonprofit entities that provide substantial dental services for continuing education credit shall:

(1) Retain patient records;

(2) Retain documentation of all pro bono assignments and the hours of service provided; and

(3) Provide the records and a copy of the assignments and the hours of service provided to the Board upon request.

J. The Board may revoke the approval status of any nonprofit entity that fails to cooperate with the Board.

K. A dental hygienist who provides pro bono dental services shall work under the direct supervision of a dentist.

L. A dentist or dental hygienist that is employed by a nonprofit entity that provides substantial pro bono dental services to the indigent or dentally underserved populations may not obtain credit for pro bono services at the entity at which the dentist or dental hygienist is employed, but may receive credit for qualified pro bono services at other nonprofit entities.

M. A dentist who is a Board-recognized specialist and who has announced a specialization shall limit the pro bono services exclusively to the announced special areas.

N. In accordance with COMAR 10.44.12, a dentist may administer general anesthesia or sedation only with the appropriate Board permit issued for the specific practice location at which the dentist wishes to administer general anesthesia or sedation.

O. A dental hygienist may administer local anesthesia by infiltration only with the appropriate Board recognition.

P. A dentist and dental hygienist who provide pro bono dental services shall:

(1) Maintain proof of such services for at least 5 years on a Board-approved form; and

(2) Provide documentation of the services to the Board on request.

Q. A dentist or dental hygienist who fails to maintain accurate and complete records of services rendered may not receive continuing education credit for those services.

R. A dentist shall use a Board-approved form for patients with clear instructions for any follow-up care.

S. A dentist or a dental hygienist under a formal or informal Board order or agreement that provides for the provision of pro bono services may not receive continuing education credit for the provision of the pro bono services.

T. Failure to comply with the provisions of this regulation constitutes unprofessional conduct.

.08 Automatically Approved Sponsors.

A. The Board approves for credit any course or program that:

(1) Satisfies all eligibility criteria in Regulations .06 and .07 of this chapter; and

(2) Is sponsored by any one of the following entities:

(a) An accredited dental school;

(b) An accredited dental hygiene school;

(c) The American Dental Association;

(d) The National Dental Association;

(e) The American Dental Hygienists' Association;

(f) The National Dental Hygiene Association;

(g) The American Medical Association;

(h) The American Hospital Association;

(i) The American Heart Association;

(j) The American Red Cross;

(k) The American Society of Dentistry for Children;

(l) Any American Dental Association recognized specialty society;

(m) The Academy of General Dentistry;

(n) The Veterans Administration;

(o) The United States uniformed services;

(p) The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services;

(q) The Maryland Department of Health;

(r) Any American Medical Association recognized specialty society;

(s) The Mid-Atlantic PANDA Coalition; and

(t) Any constituent or component organization of the groups in §A(2)(a)—(s) of this regulation.

B. The Board approves for credit any course or program that is designed to enhance the licensee’s clinical knowledge and ability to treat dental patients and is approved by any one of the following credentialing agencies:

(1) The American Dental Association Commission for Continuing Education Recognition Program (CERP);

(2) The Academy of General Dentistry Program Approval for Continuing Education (PACE);

(3) The American Association of Dental Boards Accredited Continuing Education Program (ACE); and

(4) The American Academy of Dental Hygiene (AADH).

.09 Approval and Rescission of Continuing Education Programs for Sponsors Who Are Not Automatically Approved.

A. The Board may approve individual programs of sponsors who are not automatically approved sponsors of continuing education credits under Regulation .08 of this chapter.

B. Applicants meeting the requirements of this chapter, who are not automatically approved to sponsor continuing education programs may apply to the Board at least 90 days before the scheduled program for authorization to sponsor a program.

C. The Board shall provide the applicant with an application form.

D. An applicant shall provide the following information on the application which shall be submitted to the Board along with a processing fee as set forth in COMAR 10.44.20:

(1) Full name, business address, and contact information of the sponsor;

(2) Full name of the program for which approval is sought;

(3) A program description;

(4) Program objectives;

(5) A detailed syllabus of the course;

(6) Continuing education hours requested;

(7) An overview of any examinations that shall be passed as a condition of program completion; and

(8) A sample of the certificate of completion that will be provided to program participants.

E. In addition to the requirements of §D of this regulation, the applicant shall provide the following to the Board regarding the program presenter or speaker:

(1) Full name, business address, and contact information;

(2) Current curriculum vitae;

(3) Educational background and all professional degrees earned;

(4) A list of all professional licenses or certifications held;

(5) A brief description of any other professional programs taught; and

(6) A copy of any public disciplinary orders issued by any health occupational board, including the Maryland Dental Board.

F. The Board shall give notice to the applicant that the applicant has been approved or disapproved, including a statement whether the number of approved continuing education hours is different from the number requested.

G. If a program is disapproved, the Board shall advise the applicant of the reasons for disapproval.

H. An approval of a particular program is an approval of the program and the presenter or speaker of that program.

I. A sponsor shall resubmit an application and pay a processing fee for approval of the program if:

(1) The presenter or speaker changes; or

(2) There is a significant change in the course material or course objectives.

J. Fees for approval of a continuing education program are nonrefundable.

K. A licensee or certificate holder under a Board order may not present a continuing education course or program during the pendency of their Board order.

L. A sponsor of a Board-approved continuing education program shall:

(1) Maintain records of all attendees for at least 5 years;

(2) Provide copies of program attendance to the Board upon request;

(3) Provide attendees with an opportunity to complete a program evaluation at the conclusion of the program, which shall be provided to the Board upon request; and

(4) Allow the Board to audit the program upon payment of any applicable program fees.

M. The Board may rescind approval of a continuing education course or program if it determines that:

(1) The course or program:

(a) Does not meet the requirements of Regulations .06 and .07 of this chapter; or

(b) In the Board’s sole discretion, does not meet its stated objectives; or

(2) The sponsor has committed fraud or made other misrepresentations to the Board.

.10 Certificates of Completion.

Legible certificates of program completion shall be provided to those who complete the program and shall contain at least:

A. The full name of the sponsor;

B. The full name of the program;

C. The dates of program presentation;

D. The location of the program, including whether the program was presented electronically;

E. The number of continuing education hours awarded, which may not exceed those approved by the Board;

F. The printed name and signature of the presenter or speaker;

G. A statement that the program is approved by the Board;

H. The Board’s program approval number; and

I. A statement that the sponsor maintains responsibility for the program.

.11 Advanced Clinical Training Programs for a Dentist Licensed in Another State.

A. A dentist licensed in another state who does not hold a Maryland dental license and who wishes to participate in an advanced clinical training program of postgraduate training offered as continuing education for licensed dentists shall receive written approval from the Board before participation in the advanced clinical training program as provided in Regulation .10B of this chapter.

B. At least 45 days before the commencement of an advanced clinical training program of postgraduate training offered as continuing education for licensed dentists, a dentist who is licensed in another state and who is not licensed in Maryland shall apply to the Board for written approval to participate in the advanced clinical training program as provided in Regulation .10A of this chapter.

C. To qualify to participate in an advanced clinical training program, a dentist who is licensed in another state and who does not hold a Maryland dental license shall hold a degree of Doctor of Dental Surgery or Doctor of Dental Medicine, or the equivalent, from a college or university that is authorized by any state or province of Canada to grant the degree.

.12 Advanced Clinical Training Programs — Application Procedures and Practice Limitations.

A. To apply for written approval to participate in an advanced clinical training program offered as continuing education for licensed dentists, a dentist licensed in another state who does not hold a Maryland dental license shall:

(1) Apply to the Board on a form approved by the Board;

(2) Pay a nonrefundable fee to the Board as set forth in COMAR 10.44.20;

(3) Submit to the Board a copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

(4) Submit documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

(5) Submit any other pertinent documents or information requested by the Board.

B. After review of the documentation and other pertinent information provided to the Board, the Board shall provide the applicant with a written notice stating that the application to participate in the advanced clinical training program has been approved or denied.

C. The Board's approval or denial of an application to participate in an advanced clinical training program shall apply only to the advanced clinical training program for which the applicant has made application.

D. A dentist whose application to participate in an advanced clinical training program for continuing education has been approved shall be covered by a policy of malpractice insurance during the period in which the dentist participates in the advanced clinical training program.

E. An individual who is a student of dentistry under Regulation .02B(6)(d) and (f) of this chapter may only practice dentistry in Maryland in accordance with the advanced clinical training program.

.13 Examination in Lieu of Continuing Education Requirements.

A. Successful completion of a Board-approved examination within the preceding 2-year period may be substituted for continuing education credits.

B. The Board recognizes successful completion of the following written examinations as equivalent to 30 full hours of continuing education:

(1) For dental hygienists only, the North East Regional Board's (NERB) Dental Hygiene Comprehensive Examination;

(2) NERB's Simulated Clinical Examinations;

(3) Academy of General Dentistry's Fellowship Examination;

(4) Examinations leading to recognized specialty boards' Diplomate status;

(5) National Board's Part II examination;

(6) Central Regional Dental Testing Agency's written examinations;

(7) South East Regional Testing Agency's written examinations; or

(8) Western Regional Examining Board's written examination.

.14 Audit of Continuing Education Records.

A. A dentist or dental hygienist who has completed the continuing education requirements shall attest to the completion on a form supplied by the Board as part of the application for license renewal, reinstatement, or reactivation.

B. The Board may request verification of compliance with this chapter through inspection of continuing education records maintained by licensees in accordance with Regulation .03A of this chapter.

C. Except as provided in this regulation, the Board shall audit a percentage of dentists and dental hygienists, selected by the Board for each renewal cycle.

D. A licensee who receives notice of a continuing education audit shall verify compliance with this chapter by the date specified in the notice and submit to the Board a report of the continuing education hours required for renewal on a form approved by the Board along with the appropriate documentation.

E. Documentation. A dentist or dental hygienist shall provide to the Board:

(1) A certificate of completion for approved courses or programs;

(2) Current CPR certification as specified under Regulation .04 of this chapter;

(3) If applicable, proof of Board-approved pro bono dental or dental hygiene services provided; and

(4) If a certificate of completion is not available, satisfactory proof of time spent preparing and presenting table clinics, lectures, articles for publications in dental or medical journals, or attending study clubs, or other meetings involved with performing clinical dentistry.

F. A dentist or a dental hygienist may request an extension of time to comply with the requirements of this chapter.

G. A request for an extension of time under §F of this regulation shall:

(1) Be made in writing;

(2) Detail and document the reasons the licensee was not able to complete the continuing education requirements within the allotted time; and

(3) Provide a period of time requested by the licensee to complete the required continuing education.

H. The grant of an extension and the period of the extension is within the sole discretion of the Board.

I. A dentist or dental hygienist who requests and is granted an extension of time by the Board shall be audited at the next renewal cycle.

J. A dentist or dental hygienist granted an extension of time shall attest to completion of continuing education requirements by the end of the extension period.

K. Failure to submit the required attestation or failure to meet continuing education requirements by the end of the extension period may subject the licensee to disciplinary action.

L. The Board’s staff shall conduct a preliminary review and evaluation of the documentation submitted to the Board and report their findings to the Board.

M. After the Board’s review of the submitted documentation, the Board may find one or both of the following:

(1) That the dentist or dental hygienist has not met the Board’s continuing education requirements; or

(2) That the dentist or dental hygienist has submitted courses or programs that have not been Board-approved.

N. The Board may require a dentist or a dental hygienist who has not met the Board’s continuing education requirements or who has submitted courses or programs that have not been Board-approved to take additional continuing education courses or programs in order to meet the Board’s continuing education requirements.

O. Penalties for Violation.

(1) A false, misleading, or deceptive statement on a renewal, reinstatement, or reactivation form may constitute unprofessional conduct and may result in disciplinary action against the licensee as set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland.

(2) Failure to complete continuing education requirements within the time period specified under Regulation .05 of this chapter or any applicable extension constitutes unprofessional conduct and may result in disciplinary action against the licensee as set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland.

.15 Active Military Service.

The Board may waive any or all of the requirements of this chapter for a licensee who is unable to complete the requirements due to the licensee's active military service.

Chapter 23 Unprofessional Conduct

Administrative History

Effective date: March 5, 2001 (28:4 Md. R. 419)

Regulation .01B amended effective January 19, 2004 (31:1 Md. R. 31)

Regulation .02 amended and recodified to be Regulation .03, new Regulation .02 adopted effective September 3, 2001 (28:17 Md. R. 1557)

——————

Chapter revised effective August 6, 2012 (39:15 Md. R. 964)

Regulation .01 amended effective April 14, 2014 (41:7 Md. R. 422)

——————

Chapter revised effective July 17, 2017 (44:14 Md. R.655)

Authority

Health Occupations Article, §§1-212, 4-205(c)(3), 4-315(a)(16) and (b)(3), and 4-505(a)(2) and (c)(3), Annotated Code of Maryland

.01 Definition.

A. In this chapter, the following term has the meaning indicated.

B. Term Defined. "Legitimate patient" means a patient who has an existing written dental record or who has one created within 72 hours of the patient's first communication with the dentist.

.02 Incorporation by Reference.

In this chapter, the following documents are incorporated by reference.

A. Principles of Ethics and Code of Professional Conduct (American Dental Association, With official advisory opinions revised to September 2016).

B. Bylaws — Code of Ethics (for Dental Hygienists), (American Dental Hygienists’ Association, June 23, 2014).

.03 Unprofessional or Dishonorable Conduct.

A. A dentist, dental hygienist, or dental radiation technologist may not engage in unprofessional or dishonorable conduct.

B. The following shall constitute unprofessional or dishonorable conduct in the practice of dentistry, dental hygiene, or dental radiation technology:

(1) Misrepresenting the following to a patient or the public:

(a) The description, chemical composition, or quality of the materials the licensee uses or intends to use; or

(b) Methods and techniques the licensee uses or intends to use;

(2) Engaging in conduct which is unbecoming a member of the dental profession;

(3) Representing that a dental procedure has been completed when in fact the procedure has not been completed;

(4) Permitting or failing to prevent the placement or exposure of dental radiographs by an individual not certified or otherwise qualified to do so;

(5) Committing an act of sexual misconduct as described in §C of this regulation;

(6) Performing a dental procedure without first obtaining informed consent from the patient or the patient’s legal representative;

(7) Willfully and without legal justification, failing to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board, which includes, but is not limited to:

(a) Furnishing information requested;

(b) Complying with a subpoena;

(c) Responding to a complaint at the request of the Board; and

(d) Providing meaningful and timely access to relevant patient records; or

(8) Committing any other unprofessional or dishonorable act or omission in the practice of dentistry, dental hygiene, or dental radiation technology.

C. Sexual misconduct of either a verbal or a physical nature shall include, but is not limited to:

(1) Sexual behavior with a patient in the context of a professional evaluation, treatment, procedure, or other service to the client or patient, regardless of the setting in which professional service is provided;

(2) Sexual behavior with a patient under the pretext of diagnostic or therapeutic intent or benefit;

(3) Requesting sexual favors of a patient;

(4) Touching a patient in a sexual manner;

(5) Therapeutically unnecessary discussion of sexual matters or other verbal conduct of a sexual nature while treating a patient;

(6) Taking photographs or videotapes of a patient for sexual purposes;

(7) Sexual behavior that would be considered unethical or unprofessional; or

(8) The use of a drug on a patient for the purpose of sexual behavior.

D. Dentists.

(1) In addition to the requirements stated in §§A—C of this regulation, a dentist shall comply with the Principles of Ethics and Code of Professional Conduct.

(2) It shall constitute unprofessional and dishonorable conduct for a dentist to:

(a) Self-prescribe prescription medications except that a dentist may self-prescribe when necessary to order prescription medications for dental office inventory for patient use only;

(b) Prescribe prescription medications for individuals who are not legitimate patients;

(c) Prescribe prescription medications to legitimate patients other than for therapeutic purposes;

(d) Sell, prescribe, trade, give away, or administer a prescription drug for any illegal or illegitimate purpose;

(e) Treat family members or staff differently than any other patient by:

(i) Not maintaining accurate records of all treatment provided in accordance with COMAR 10.44.30, including financial records and records of all medication prescribed; and

(ii) Not adhering to all record retention requirements in accordance with Health General Article, §4-403, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

(f) Fail to comply with the requirements of the Prescription Drug Monitoring Program as established in Health-General Article, Title 21, Subtitle 2A, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 10.47.07.

E. Dental Hygienists. In addition to the requirements stated in §§A — C of this regulation, a dental hygienist shall comply with the Bylaws — Code of Ethics (for Dental Hygienists).

.04 Penalties.

A. A dentist who violates this chapter is subject to the sanctions enumerated in Health Occupations Article, §4-315(a), Annotated Code of Maryland.

B. A dental hygienist who violates this chapter is subject to the sanctions enumerated in Health Occupations Article, §4-315(b), Annotated Code of Maryland.

C. A dental radiation technologist who violates this chapter is subject to the sanctions enumerated in COMAR 10.44.19.11A.

Chapter 24 Retired Volunteer Licenses

Administrative History

Effective date: June 25, 2001 (28:12 Md. R. 1110)

——————

Regulations .01—.07 repealed and new Regulations .01—.08 adopted effective December 11, 2003 (30:24 Md. R. 1743)

——————

Chapter revised effective July 18, 2005 (32:14 Md. R. 1276)

Authority

Health Occupations Article,§§4-101, 4-302, 4-304, and 4-308, Annotated Code of Maryland; Ch. 237, Acts of 2003

.01 Use of License.

The license of a retired volunteer dentist or a retired volunteer dental hygienist shall be used only for volunteer services and not for compensation.

.02 Qualifications for a Retired Volunteer License.

To qualify for a retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license, a dentist or dental hygienist shall:

A. Be of good moral character;

B. Have had an active general license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in Maryland within the past 2 years;

C. Meet the qualifications otherwise required by Health Occupations Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland, for an active general license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in the State, except that the North East Regional Board examination requirements are waived by the Board;

D. Complete the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in the State; and

E. Provide dental or dental hygiene services as set forth in Regulation .06 of this chapter.

.03 Application for a Retired Volunteer License.

To apply for a retired volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene, a dentist or dental hygienist shall submit:

A. A completed application on a form provided by the Board;

B. A photograph of the applicant not to exceed 3 inches by 3 inches accompanied by a notarized statement stating that the "photograph is a true photograph of me";

C. A certified letter with a raised embossed seal from the licensing authority of each state in which the applicant holds an active dental or dental hygiene license, or ever held an active dental or dental hygiene license, indicating that the license is or was in good standing and whether the applicant:

(1) Is being investigated;

(2) Has charges pending against the applicant's license;

(3) Has been disciplined; or

(4) Has been convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland;

D. A copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

E. A notarized affidavit stating that the dentist or dental hygienist will donate at least 100 hours of dental or dental hygiene services without compensation;

F. Evidence that the dentist or dental hygienist is covered by malpractice insurance as set forth in Regulation .04 of this chapter;

G. Documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

H. Any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

.04 Malpractice Insurance Requirement for Initial Licensure and Renewal.

A. An applicant for a retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license and an applicant for the renewal of a retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license shall be covered by malpractice insurance.

B. If the malpractice insurance consists of a personal policy of malpractice insurance, the dentist or dental hygienist shall provide the Board with evidence of the insurance which shall consist of:

(1) The name of the insurance provider;

(2) The name, address, and telephone number of the insured's agent, or if the insured has no agent, the address and telephone number of the insurance provider;

(3) The policy number;

(4) The amounts of coverage; and

(5) The expiration date of the policy.

C. If the malpractice insurance is provided from or through the institution at which the applicant is to provide volunteer services, the dentist or dental hygienist shall provide the Board with evidence of the insurance which shall consist of:

(1) The name of the insurance provider;

(2) The amounts of coverage;

(3) The expiration date of the policy or coverage; and

(4) A letter from the institution verifying the intent of the institution to provide malpractice insurance.

.05 Licensure of Retired Volunteer Dentists and Dental Hygienists.

A. A dentist or dental hygienist shall be granted a retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license if the dentist or dental hygienist:

(1) Meets the qualifications for licensure as a retired volunteer dentist or dental hygienist; and

(2) Is covered by a personal policy of malpractice insurance.

B. A dentist or dental hygienist shall be granted a retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license that is site-specific to the institution at which the dentist or dental hygienist is to provide the volunteer services if the dentist or dental hygienist:

(1) Meets the qualifications for licensure as a retired volunteer dentist or dental hygienist; and

(2) Is covered with malpractice insurance from or through the institution at which the dentist or dental hygienist is to provide volunteer services.

C. A dentist or dental hygienist who has been granted a site-specific retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license shall practice dentistry or dental hygiene only at the institution named on the license.

.06 Scope of Practice.

A. A dentist or dental hygienist with a retired volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in the State shall practice only:

(1) In a dental office;

(2) In a dental clinic;

(3) In an ambulatory care facility;

(4) In a hospital; or

(5) For an entity providing medical care to the poor, the elderly, or handicapped that is operated:

(a) By the State;

(b) By a local government;

(c) By a bona fide charitable organization; or

(d) In any other setting approved by the Board.

B. A dentist or dental hygienist with a retired volunteer license may not receive compensation for practicing dentistry or dental hygiene in the State.

.07 Expiration Date of Licenses.

A retired volunteer license to practice dentistry and a retired volunteer license to practice dental hygiene expire on June 30 of the second year following the effective date of the license.

.08 Renewal of Licenses.

Before a retired volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional term if the licensee:

A. Submits a completed renewal application on a form provided by the Board;

B. Completes the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in the State;

C. Submits proof satisfactory to the Board that the dentist has donated at least 100 hours of dental services, or that the dental hygienist has donated at least 100 hours of dental hygiene services, without compensation;

D. Provides evidence that the dentist or dental hygienist is covered by malpractice insurance as set forth in Regulation .04 of this chapter;

E. Submits a copy of the licensee's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

F. Submits documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the licensee's name; and

G. Submits any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

.09 Surrender of License.

A. A dentist or a dental hygienist who has been granted a site-specific retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license shall immediately surrender the license to the Board when the dentist or dental hygienist ceases to:

(1) Provide volunteer dental or dental hygiene services at the institution named on the license; or

(2) Be covered by malpractice insurance from or through the institution named on the license.

B. A dentist or a dental hygienist who has been granted a retired volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license that is not site-specific shall immediately surrender the license to the Board when the dentist or dental hygienist ceases to be covered by malpractice insurance.

.10 Fees.

There is no fee for an initial retired volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene, and there is no fee for the renewal of a retired volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene.

.11 Violations.

Violations of this chapter pertaining to the use of a retired volunteer license constitute unprofessional conduct and may result in disciplinary action against the licensee as set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Chapter 25 Compelling Public Purpose

Administrative History

Effective date: December 24, 2001 (28:25 Md. R. 2192)

Authority

Health Occupations Article, §4-205; State Government Article, §10-617(h)(3); Annotated Code of Maryland

.01 Disclosure for Compelling Public Purpose.

The Board may find that a compelling public purpose warrants disclosure of information in a certification, licensing, or investigative file, regardless of whether there has been a request for the information, if the information concerns:

A. Possible criminal activity, and is disclosed to a federal, state, or local law enforcement or prosecutorial official or authority;

B. A possible violation of law, and is disclosed to a federal, state, or local authority that has jurisdiction over the individual whose conduct may be a violation, and the information disclosed is limited to information relevant to the possible violation by that individual; or

C. Conduct by an individual which the Board reasonably believes may pose a risk to the public health, safety, or welfare, and is disclosed to a law enforcement authority, administrative official or agency that regulates the individual, or to a hospital or other health care facility where the individual has privileges.

.02 Other Disclosures.

This chapter does not prevent or limit the ability of the Board to disclose general licensing information as provided in State Government Article, §10-617(h), Annotated Code of Maryland, or any information which the Board may otherwise disclose by law.

Chapter 26 Volunteer Licenses

Administrative History

Effective date: December 11, 2003 (30:24 Md. R. 1743)

Regulation .07 amended effective August 16, 2004 (31:16 Md. R. 1256)

——————

Chapter revised effective July 18, 2005 (32:14 Md. R. 1276)

Authority

Health Occupations Article, §§4-101, 4-302, 4-304, and 4-308, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Ch. 237, Acts of 2003

.01 Scope.

The license of a volunteer dentist or a volunteer dental hygienist shall be used for volunteer services and not for compensation.

.02 Qualifications — Dentist Who Has Passed a Regional Board.

To qualify for a volunteer dentist's license, a dentist who has passed a regional board as defined in Health Occupations Article, §4-306(a)(3), Annotated Code of Maryland, shall:

A. Be of good moral character;

B. Be 18 years old or older;

C. Hold a Degree of Doctor of Dental Surgery, Doctor of Dental Medicine, or the equivalent from a college or university that is:

(1) Authorized by any state or province of Canada to grant the degree; and

(2) Recognized by the Board as:

(a) Requiring adequate preprofessional collegiate training; and

(b) Maintaining an acceptable course of dental instruction;

D. Pass the NERB dental written examinations;

E. Pass the Maryland Jurisprudence Examination on the Maryland State Dental Law;

F. Hold an active license to practice dentistry in another state or in the District of Columbia;

G. Meet the qualifications otherwise required for a general license to practice dentistry by Health Occupations Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland;

H. Complete the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dentistry; and

I. Provide dental services as set forth in Regulation .11 of this chapter.

.03 Qualifications — Dentist Who Has Not Passed a Regional Board.

A. To qualify for a volunteer dentist's license, a dentist who has not passed a regional board shall:

(1) Be of good moral character;

(2) Be 18 years old or older;

(3) Hold a Degree of Doctor of Dental Surgery, Doctor of Dental Medicine, or the equivalent from a college or university that is:

(a) Authorized by any state or province of Canada to grant the degree; and

(b) Recognized by the Board as:

(i) Requiring adequate preprofessional collegiate training; and

(ii) Maintaining an acceptable course of dental instruction;

(4) Submit a notarized affidavit or other evidence satisfactory to the Board indicating that during the 5 years preceding application the applicant has actively engaged in practicing dentistry for at least 850 hours;

(5) Pass the NERB dental written examinations;

(6) Pass the Maryland Jurisprudence Examination on the Maryland State Dental Law;

(7) Hold an active license to practice dentistry in another state or in the District of Columbia;

(8) Meet the qualifications otherwise required for a general license to practice dentistry by Health Occupations Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland;

(9) Complete the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dentistry; and

(10) Provide dental services as set forth in Regulation .11 of this chapter.

B. If occurring during the 5 years preceding an application, the practice of dentistry in the armed forces, state and federal programs, and intern and residency programs counts toward the required hours of active practice.

.04 Qualifications — Dental Hygienist Who Has Passed a Regional Board.

To qualify for a volunteer dental hygienist's license, a dental hygienist who has passed a regional board as defined in Health Occupations Article, §4-306(a)(3), Annotated Code of Maryland, shall:

A. Be of good moral character;

B. Be a graduate of a school for dental hygienists that:

(1) Requires at least 2 years of education in an institution of higher education;

(2) Is accredited by the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation; and

(3) Is approved by the Board;

C. Pass the Maryland Jurisprudence Examination on the Maryland State Dental Law;

D. Hold an active license to practice dental hygiene in another state or in the District of Columbia;

E. Meet the qualifications otherwise required for a general license to practice dental hygiene by Health Occupations Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland;

F. Complete the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dental hygiene; and

G. Provide dental hygiene services as set forth in Regulation .11 of this chapter.

.05 Qualifications — Dental Hygienist Who Has Not Passed a Regional Board.

A. To qualify for a volunteer dental hygienist's license, a dental hygienist who has not passed a regional board shall:

(1) Be of good moral character;

(2) Be a graduate of a school for dental hygienists that:

(a) Requires at least 2 years of education in an institution of higher education;

(b) Is accredited by the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation; and

(c) Is approved by the Board;

(3) Submit a notarized affidavit or other evidence satisfactory to the Board indicating that during the 3 years preceding application the applicant has actively engaged in practicing dental hygiene for at least 150 hours;

(4) Pass the Maryland Jurisprudence Examination on the Maryland State Dental Law;

(5) Hold an active license to practice dental hygiene in another state or in the District of Columbia;

(6) Meet the qualifications otherwise required for a general license to practice dental hygiene by Health Occupations Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland;

(7) Complete the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dental hygiene; and

(8) Provide dental hygiene services as set forth in Regulation .11 of this chapter.

B. The practice of dental hygiene in the armed forces, state, or federal programs within the 3 years preceding application counts toward the required hours of active practice.

.06 Application — Dentist or Dental Hygienist Who Has Passed a Regional Board.

A. To apply for a volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene, a dentist or a dental hygienist who has passed a regional board in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §4-306, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall submit:

(1) A completed application on a form provided by the Board;

(2) A photograph of the applicant not to exceed 3 inches by 3 inches accompanied by a notarized statement stating that "the photograph is a true photograph of me";

(3) An original National Board Score Card;

(4) Certified proof of dental or dental hygiene education which contains the raised embossed school seal certifying its authenticity, except that letters from educational institutions on original letterhead bearing an original signature do not require a raised embossed seal;

(5) A certified examination score of a regional board;

(6) A certified letter with a raised embossed seal from the dental or dental hygiene licensing authority of each state in which the applicant holds an active dental or dental hygiene license or ever held an active dental or dental hygiene license indicating that the licensee is or was in good standing and that the applicant:

(a) Is not being investigated;

(b) Does not have charges pending against the applicant's license;

(c) Has not been disciplined;

(d) Has not been convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland;

(7) A copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

(8) A notarized affidavit stating that the dentist or dental hygienist will donate at least 100 hours of dental or dental hygiene services without compensation;

(9) Evidence that the dentist or dental hygienist is covered by malpractice insurance as set forth in Regulation .09 of this chapter;

(10) Documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

(11) Any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

B. In addition to the requirement of §A(5) of this regulation that a dentist submit a certified examination score of a regional board, a dentist, if requested by the State Dental Board, shall submit a specific point breakdown by procedure including penalty deductions.

.07 Application — Dentist or Dental Hygienist Who Has Not Passed a Regional Board.

To apply for a volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene, a dentist or a dental hygienist who has not passed a regional board in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §4-306, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall submit:

A. A completed application on a form provided by the Board;

B. A photograph of the applicant not to exceed 3 inches by 3 inches accompanied by a notarized statement stating that "the photograph is a true photograph of me";

C. An original National Board Score Card;

D. Certified proof of dental or dental hygiene education which contains the raised embossed school seal certifying its authenticity, except that letters from educational institutions on original letterhead, bearing an original signature do not require a raised embossed seal;

E. A certified letter with a raised embossed seal from the dental or dental hygiene licensing authority of each state in which the applicant holds an active dental or dental hygiene license or ever held an active dental or dental hygiene license indicating that the licensee is or was in good standing and that the applicant:

(1) Is not being investigated;

(2) Does not have charges pending against the applicant's license;

(3) Has not been disciplined;

(4) Has not been convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland;

F. A copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

G. A notarized affidavit stating that the dentist or dental hygienist will donate at least 100 hours of dental or dental hygiene services without compensation;

H. Evidence that the dentist or dental hygienist is covered by malpractice insurance as set forth in Regulation .09 of this chapter;

I. Documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

J. Any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

.08 Proof of Active Practice of Dentistry or Dental Hygiene.

A. In addition to the requirements of Regulation .07 of this chapter, a dentist who has not passed a regional board in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §4-306, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall submit a notarized affidavit or other evidence satisfactory to the Board indicating that during the 5 years preceding application, the dentist has actively engaged in practicing dentistry for at least 850 hours.

B. In addition to the requirements of Regulation .05 of this chapter, a dental hygienist who has not passed a regional board in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §4-306, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall submit a notarized affidavit or other evidence satisfactory to the Board indicating that during the 3 years preceding application, the dental hygienist has actively engaged in practicing dental hygiene for at least 150 hours.

.09 Malpractice Insurance Requirement for Initial Licensure and Renewal.

A. An applicant for a volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license, and an applicant for the renewal of a volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license, shall be covered by malpractice insurance.

B. If the malpractice insurance consists of a personal policy of malpractice insurance, the dentist or dental hygienist shall provide the Board with evidence of the insurance which shall consist of:

(1) The name of the insurance provider;

(2) The name, address, and telephone number of the insured's agent, or if the insured has no agent, the address and telephone number of the insurance provider;

(3) The policy number;

(4) The amounts of coverage; and

(5) The expiration date of the policy.

C. If the malpractice insurance is provided from or through the institution at which the applicant is to provide volunteer services, the dentist or dental hygienist shall provide the Board with evidence of the insurance which shall consist of:

(1) The name of the insurance provider;

(2) The amounts of coverage;

(3) The expiration date of the policy or coverage; and

(4) A letter from the institution verifying the intent of the institution to provide malpractice insurance.

.10 Licensure of Volunteer Dentists and Dental Hygienists.

A. A dentist or dental hygienist shall be granted a volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license if the dentist or dental hygienist:

(1) Meets the qualifications for licensure as a volunteer dentist or dental hygienist; and

(2) Is covered by a personal policy of malpractice insurance.

B. A dentist or dental hygienist shall be granted a volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license that is site-specific to the institution at which the dentist or dental hygienist is to provide the volunteer services if the dentist or dental hygienist:

(1) Meets the qualifications for licensure as a volunteer dentist or dental hygienist; and

(2) Is covered with malpractice insurance from or through the institution at which the dentist or dental hygienist is to provide volunteer services.

C. A dentist or dental hygienist who has been granted a site-specific volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license shall practice dentistry or dental hygiene only at the institution named on the license.

.11 Scope of Practice.

A. A dentist or dental hygienist with a volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in the State shall practice only:

(1) In a dental office;

(2) In a dental clinic;

(3) In an ambulatory care facility;

(4) In a hospital; or

(5) For an entity providing medical care to the poor, the elderly, or handicapped that is operated:

(a) By the State;

(b) By a local government;

(c) By a bona fide charitable organization; or

(d) In any other setting approved by the Board.

.12 Expiration Date of Licenses.

A volunteer license to practice dentistry and a volunteer license to practice dental hygiene expire on June 30 of the second year following the effective date of the license.

.13 Renewal of Licenses.

Before a volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene expires, the licensee may renew it for an additional term if the licensee:

A. Submits a completed renewal application on a form provided by the Board;

B. Completes the continuing education requirements for an active general license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene in the State;

C. Submits proof satisfactory to the Board that the dentist or dental hygienist has donated at least 100 hours of dental or dental hygiene services without compensation;

D. Submits evidence that the dentist or dental hygienist is covered by malpractice insurance as set forth in Regulation .09 of this chapter;

E. Submits documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

F. Submits any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

.14 Surrender of License.

A. A dentist or a dental hygienist who has been granted a site-specific volunteer dentist or dental hygienist's license shall immediately surrender the license to the Board if the dentist or dental hygienist ceases to:

(1) Provide volunteer dental or dental hygiene services at the institution named on the license; or

(2) Be covered by malpractice insurance from or through the institution named on the license.

B. A dentist or a dental hygienist who has been granted a volunteer dentist's or dental hygienist's license that is not site-specific shall immediately surrender the license to the Board if the dentist or dental hygienist ceases to be covered by malpractice insurance.

.15 Fees.

There is no fee for an initial volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene, and there is no fee for the renewal of a volunteer license to practice dentistry or dental hygiene.

.16 Violations.

Violations of this chapter pertaining to the use of a volunteer license constitute unprofessional conduct and may result in disciplinary action against the licensee as set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Chapter 27 Dental Hygiene Practice — General Supervision — Private Office

Administrative History

Effective date: December 11, 2003 (30:24 Md. R. 1743)

Regulation .04E amended effective March 3, 2014 (41:4 Md. R. 301)

Authority

Health Occupations Article, §4-308, Annotated Code of Maryland; Ch. 221, Acts of 2003

.01 Scope.

This chapter governs the practice of dental hygiene in a private dental office. The practice of dental hygiene in a facility is governed by COMAR 10.44.21.

.02 Definition.

A. In this chapter, the following term has the meaning indicated.

B. Term Defined. "General supervision" means the supervision of a dental hygienist by a dentist in a private dental office where the dentist may or may not be present when the dental hygienist performs the dental hygiene procedures.

.03 Supervision Requirements in a Private Dental Office.

While it is effective, a general license to practice dental hygiene issued under Health Occupations Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland, authorizes the licensee to practice dental hygiene under the general supervision of a licensed dentist in a private dental office pursuant to the provisions of Health Occupations Article, §4-308(i), Annotated Code of Maryland.

.04 Guidelines for Operating under General Supervision in a Private Dental Office.

A. In addition to the requirements contained in Health Occupations Article, §4-308(l), Annotated Code of Maryland, if a dental hygienist works under general supervision in a private dental office where a dentist is not on the premises while authorized dental hygiene services are provided, the requirements in §§B—F of this regulation shall be met.

B. Both the private dental office and the dental hygienist shall maintain written documentation of at least 1,500 hours of dental hygiene clinical practice in direct patient care before commencing practice.

C. Before an appointment, the patient or the custodial parent or legal guardian of a minor or incompetent adult shall:

(1) Be informed that a dental hygienist will be providing services previously prescribed by a dentist who will not be on the premises during the appointment; and

(2) Consent in writing to receiving the dental hygiene services.

D. A copy of the signed consent shall be maintained in the patient's record.

E. The number of unsupervised clinical hours worked by a dental hygienist in any given 3-month period shall be less than 60 percent of the dental hygienist’s total hours worked during that 3-month period. To insure compliance with this provision, the supervising dentist and the dental hygienist shall maintain a written record of the dental hygienist’s total monthly hours worked and the total number of monthly hours worked by the dental hygienist when a dentist was not on the premises.

F. A supervising dentist may not have more than two dental hygienists working under the dentist's general supervision at any given time, regardless of the number of offices in which the supervising dentist practices dentistry.

.05 Penalties.

A violation of this chapter by a dentist or dental hygienist is unprofessional conduct.

Chapter 28 Teachers' Licenses for Graduates of United States or Canadian Dental Schools and Schools of Dental Hygiene

Administrative History

Effective date: January 6, 2005 (31:26 Md. R. 1863)

Authority

Health Occupations Article, §§4-302 and 4-303, Annotated Code of Maryland

.01 Scope.

A. This chapter establishes the requirements for:

(1) A teacher's license to practice dentistry for a graduate of a United States or Canadian dental school; and

(2) A teacher's license to practice dental hygiene for a graduate of a United States or Canadian school for dental hygienists.

B. The requirements for a teacher's license to practice dentistry for a graduate of a foreign dental school are set forth in COMAR 10.44.02.

.02 Requirements for Teacher's License to Practice Dentistry.

A. To qualify for a teacher's license to practice dentistry, an applicant shall meet the requirements set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-302, Annotated Code of Maryland.

B. An applicant for a teacher's license to practice dentistry shall submit the following to the Board:

(1) A completed application on a form provided by the Board;

(2) A photograph of the applicant not to exceed 3 inches by 3 inches accompanied by a notarized statement that "the photograph is a true photograph of me" ;

(3) Certified proof of dental education with the raised embossed school seal certifying its authenticity, except that letters from educational institutions on original letterhead and bearing an original signature do not require a raised embossed seal;

(4) A certified letter with a raised embossed seal from the dental licensing authority of each state in which the applicant holds an active dental license or ever held an active dental license, indicating that the license is or was in good standing, and that the applicant:

(a) Is not being investigated;

(b) Does not have charges pending against the applicant's license;

(c) Has not been disciplined; and

(d) Has not been convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland;

(5) Proof satisfactory to the Board that the applicant has at least 5 years of active dental experience;

(6) A copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

(7) A letter from the Dean of the college or university in which the applicant is to teach a subject required by the dental school of that college or university:

(a) Requesting that the license be issued; and

(b) Indicating that the applicant is to be a full-time faculty member;

(8) Documentation of a change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

(9) Any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

C. The practice of dentistry in the armed forces, state and federal programs, and intern and residency programs within the 5 years preceding application shall count toward the required active dental experience.

.03 Requirements for Teacher's License to Practice Dental Hygiene.

A. To qualify for a teacher's license to practice dental hygiene, an applicant shall meet the requirements set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-302, Annotated Code of Maryland.

B. An applicant for a teacher's license to practice dental hygiene shall submit the following to the Board:

(1) A completed application on a form provided by the Board;

(2) A photograph of the applicant not to exceed 3 inches by 3 inches accompanied by a notarized statement that "the photograph is a true photograph of me" ;

(3) Certified proof of dental hygiene education with the raised embossed school seal certifying its authenticity, except that letters from educational institutions on original letterhead and bearing an original signature do not require a raised embossed seal;

(4) A certified letter with a raised embossed seal from the dental hygiene licensing authority of each state in which the applicant holds an active dental hygiene license or ever held an active dental hygiene license, indicating that the license is or was in good standing and that the applicant:

(a) Is not being investigated;

(b) Does not have charges pending against the applicant's license;

(c) Has not been disciplined; and

(d) Has not been convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland;

(5) Proof satisfactory to the Board that the applicant has at least 5 years of active dental hygiene experience;

(6) A copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

(7) A letter from the Dean of the college or university in which the applicant is to teach a subject required by the dental hygiene school or dental school of that college or university:

(a) Requesting that the license be issued; and

(b) Indicating that the applicant is to be a full-time faculty member;

(8) Documentation of change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

(9) Any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

C. The practice of dental hygiene in the armed forces, state and federal programs, and intern and residency programs within the 5 years preceding application shall count toward the required active dental hygiene experience.

.04 License to Teach Dentistry at the University of Maryland Dental School.

A. A graduate of a United States or Canadian dental school who is not licensed to practice dentistry in another state and who wishes to obtain a teacher's license to teach dentistry at the University of Maryland Dental School, shall meet the requirements set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-303(c), Annotated Code of Maryland.

B. A graduate of a United States or Canadian dental school who is not licensed to practice dentistry in another state and who wishes to apply for a teacher's license to teach dentistry at the University of Maryland Dental School shall submit the following to the Board:

(1) A completed application on a form provided by the Board;

(2) A photograph of the applicant not to exceed 3 inches by 3 inches accompanied by a notarized statement that "the photograph is a true photograph of me" ;

(3) Certified proof of dental education with the raised embossed school seal certifying its authenticity, except that letters from educational institutions on original letterhead and bearing an original signature do not require a raised embossed seal;

(4) A certified letter with a raised embossed seal from the dental licensing authority of each state in which the applicant ever held an active dental license indicating that the license is or was in good standing and that the applicant:

(a) Is not being investigated;

(b) Does not have charges pending against the applicant's license;

(c) Has not been disciplined; and

(d) Has not been convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland;

(5) Proof satisfactory to the Board that the applicant has at least 5 years of clinical dental experience;

(6) A copy of the applicant's National Practitioner Data Bank file;

(7) A letter from the Dean of the University of Maryland Dental School:

(a) Providing the reasons why the Board should waive the requirement that the applicant be licensed in another state; and

(b) Indicating that the applicant is to be a full-time faculty member;

(8) Documentation of a change of name if the name on any of the documents submitted to the Board differs from the applicant's name; and

(9) Any other documents or information pertinent to licensure required by the Board.

.05 Fees.

A. The applicant shall submit the fee specified in COMAR 10.44.20 with the application for a teacher's license to practice:

(1) Dentistry; or

(2) Dental hygiene.

B. The application fee is nonrefundable.

.06 License Void.

A teacher's license to practice dentistry and a teacher's license to practice dental hygiene in the State are immediately void upon leaving the faculty position.

Chapter 29 Nominations and Balloting for Appointments to Board of Dental Examiners

Administrative History

Effective date:

Regulations .01 — .19 adopted as an emergency provision effective January 23, 2009 (36:4 Md. R. 345); emergency status extended to July 1, 2009 (36:10 Md. R. 715); emergency status expired

——————

Regulations .01 — .16 adopted as an emergency provision effective April 6, 2010 (37:10 Md. R. 718); adopted permanently effective June 28, 2010 (37:13 Md. R. 852)

Authority

Health Occupations Article, §4-202, Annotated Code of Maryland

.01 Scope.

In accordance with Health Occupations Article, §4-202, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Governor appoints the dentist and dental hygienist Board members, with the advice of the Secretary of Health, from a list of names submitted to the Governor by the Board. This chapter covers the nomination and balloting process that will result in that list of names. The process of choosing consumer Board members is not covered by this chapter.

.02 Definitions.

A. In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

B. Terms Defined.

(1) "Board" means the Maryland State Board of Dental Examiners.

(2) Dental Hygienist.

(a) "Dental hygienist" means an individual who, on the date of the mailing of the Board's notice referred to in Regulation .04B(1) of this chapter, holds a current Maryland:

(i) General license to practice dental hygiene;

(ii) Teacher's license to practice dental hygiene;

(iii) Retired volunteer license to practice dental hygiene;

(iv) Volunteer license to practice dental hygiene; or

(v) Temporary license to practice dental hygiene.

(b) "Dental hygienist" does not include an individual who holds a dental hygienist inactive status registration certificate.

(3) Dentist.

(a) "Dentist" means an individual who, on the date of the mailing of the Board's notice referred to in Regulation .03B(1) of this chapter, holds a current Maryland:

(i) General license to practice dentistry;

(ii) Limited license to practice dentistry;

(iii) Teacher's license to practice dentistry;

(iv) Retired volunteer license to practice dentistry; or

(v) Volunteer license to practice dentistry.

(b) "Dentist" does not include an individual who holds a dentist inactive status registration certificate.

(4) "Electronic mail (e-mail)" means a message sent or received electronically over a computer network.

(5) "State dental hygienist organization affiliated with a national organization" means:

(a) An affiliation of dental hygienists who have current membership in a common and distinct Maryland dental hygienist organization or association that is committed to serving generally accepted interests in dental hygiene;

(b) An affiliation that is formed pursuant to the laws of Maryland; and

(c) A constituent organization of a national dental hygienist organization that is:

(i) Committed to serving generally accepted interests in dental hygiene; and

(ii) Formed pursuant to the laws of the state in which it was formed.

(6) "State dental organization affiliated with a national organization" means:

(a) An affiliation of dentists who have current membership in a common and distinct Maryland dental organization or association that is committed to serving generally accepted interests in dentistry;

(b) An affiliation that is formed pursuant to the laws of Maryland; and

(c) A constituent organization of a national dental organization which is:

(i) Committed to serving generally accepted interests in dentistry; and

(ii) Formed pursuant to the laws of the state in which it was formed.

.03 Notice to Fill Vacancies for Dentist Board Members.

A. General. If there are one or more dentist vacancies on the Board, the Board shall hold an annual election to elect nominees to fill the dentist vacancies.

B. Notice.

(1) The Board shall send notice of the election referred to in §A of this regulation by regular mail to:

(a) Each dentist to the last known address on file with the Board; and

(b) Each properly registered State dental organization affiliated with a national organization, to the address known to the Board.

(2) The notice referred to in §B(1) of this regulation shall:

(a) Advise the recipient of the:

(i) Number of vacancies that exist on the Board; and

(ii) Terms of office for each vacancy;

(b) Solicit nominations for each vacancy;

(c) State that a nomination petition form may be requested from the Board;

(d) State the date by which the completed nomination petition form shall be returned to the Board;

(e) State that a dentist may vote for a single candidate in the election;

(f) State the dates at which time voting by e-mail shall be permitted;

(g) State that in lieu of an e-mail ballot a dentist may request a paper ballot from the Board which shall be completed and submitted by a certain date; and

(h) Advise the recipient that the results of the balloting will be posted on the Board's website.

C. In addition to the notice mailed by regular mail described in §B of this regulation, the Board or its designee may send an e-mail notice of the election to each dentist to the last known e-mail address on file with the Board.

D. The e-mail notice described in §C of this regulation shall contain the information described in §B(2) of this regulation.

E. Nominations — Criteria.

(1) Candidates.

(a) A candidate's name may appear on the ballot only once.

(b) A State dental organization affiliated with a national organization shall only nominate a candidate who is a member of the organization.

(2) Dentist.

(a) A dentist may not nominate more than one candidate.

(b) A dentist may be both a petitioner and a candidate.

(c) A dentist who is a petitioner but not a candidate is counted as one of the ten dentists who support the nomination.

(d) A dentist who is a petitioner and a candidate is not counted as one of the ten dentists who support the nomination.

(3) Dentist and a State Dental Organization Affiliated with a National Organization.

(a) A dentist and a State dental organization affiliated with a national organization may nominate a candidate to fill a dentist vacancy on the Board.

(b) A dentist or a State dental organization affiliated with a national organization may not nominate more than one candidate.

(c) If a dentist or a State dental organization affiliated with a national organization nominates more than one candidate, each Board-approved nomination petition form submitted by the dentist or State dental organization affiliated with a national organization is invalid.

F. Nomination Petition Form. The Board-approved nomination petition form referred to in §B(2)(c) of this regulation shall:

(1) Include:

(a) The candidate's name;

(b) The candidate's address on file with the Board;

(c) The candidate's license number on file with the Board;

(d) The names of the petitioners; and

(e) The license numbers of the petitioners on file with the Board;

(2) Be signed:

(a) By the candidate;

(b) By the petitioner;

(c) If the petitioner is a State dental organization affiliated with a national organization, by its:

(i) President;

(ii) Executive director; or

(iii) Administrator; and

(d) By ten dentists who support the nomination; and

(3) Include on separate pages, not greater than 8-1/2 inches wide by 11 inches in length, and not exceeding two pages of 12-point type:

(a) The candidate's biographical information;

(b) The candidate's resume; or

(c) The candidate's curriculum vitae.

G. Board-approved nomination petition forms for dentists and for State dental organizations affiliated with a national organization shall be available from the Board upon request.

H. Filing of Nomination Petition Form.

(1) The petitioner shall deliver the original nomination petition form and supporting documents to the offices of the Board:

(a) On or before the date specified in the Board's notice; and

(b) During normal business hours.

(2) The Board may not accept the filing of any document by:

(a) Electronic facsimile transmittal; or

(b) E-mail.

(3) A nomination petition form is invalid if:

(a) It is received by the Board after the date specified in the Board's notice, regardless of the date of postmark; or

(b) It does not otherwise meet the requirements of this chapter.

I. A State dental organization affiliated with a national organization shall be properly registered with the Board to nominate a candidate.

J. Posting of Candidates.

(1) The Board shall post the names and the biographical information, resumes, or curriculum vitae of the candidates on its website.

(2) Biographical information, resumes, or curriculum vitae that do not meet the requirements of §F(3) of this regulation may not be posted on the Board's website.

.04 Notice to Fill Vacancies for Dental Hygienist Board Members.

A. General. If there are one or more dental hygienist vacancies on the Board, the Board shall hold an annual election to elect nominees to fill the dental hygienist vacancies.

B. Notice.

(1) The Board shall send notice of the election referred to in §A of this regulation by regular mail to:

(a) Each dental hygienist to the last known address on file with the Board; and

(b) Each properly registered State dental hygienist organization affiliated with a national organization, to the address known to the Board.

(2) The notice referred to in §B(1) of this regulation shall:

(a) Advise the recipient of the:

(i) Number of vacancies that exist on the Board; and

(ii) Terms of office for each vacancy;

(b) Solicit nominations for each vacancy;

(c) State that a nomination petition form may be requested from the Board;

(d) State the date by which the completed nomination petition form shall be returned to the Board;

(e) State that a dental hygienist may vote for a single candidate in the election;

(f) State the dates at which time voting by e-mail shall be permitted;

(g) State that in lieu of an e-mail ballot a dental hygienist may request a paper ballot from the Board which shall be completed and submitted by a certain date; and

(h) Advise the recipient that the results of the balloting will be posted on the Board's website.

C. In addition to the notice mailed by regular mail described in §B of this regulation, the Board or its designee may send an e-mail notice of the election to each dental hygienist to the last known e-mail address on file with the Board.

D. The e-mail notice described in §C of this regulation shall contain the information described in §B(2) of this regulation.

E. Nominations-Criteria.

(1) Candidates.

(a) A candidate's name may appear on the ballot only once.

(b) A State dental hygienist organization affiliated with a national organization shall only nominate a candidate who is a member of the organization.

(2) Dental Hygienist.

(a) A dental hygienist may not nominate more than one candidate.

(b) A dental hygienist may be both a petitioner and a candidate.

(c) A dental hygienist who is a petitioner but not a candidate is counted as one of the ten dental hygienists who support the nomination.

(d) A dental hygienist who is a petitioner and a candidate is not counted as one of the ten dental hygienists who support the nomination.

(3) Dental Hygienists and a State Dental Hygienist Organization Affiliated with a National Organization.

(a) A dental hygienist and a State dental hygienist organization affiliated with a national organization may nominate a candidate to fill a dental hygienist vacancy on the Board.

(b) A dental hygienist or a State dental hygienist organization affiliated with a national organization may not nominate more than one candidate.
